title: What Paramount’s pending purchase of Warner Bros. Discovery means for sports fans
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Paramount's acquisition of Warner Bros. Discovery for $110 billion is pending regulatory approval.
CBS and TNT/TBS, part of the acquisition, could see integrated sports broadcasts, enhancing NCAA, MLB, and NHL coverage.
Netflix exited the bidding, leaving future NFL rights negotiations as potential area for competition with Paramount.

title: Patriots reportedly interested in A.J. Brown, but not at Eagles’ current asking price
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Patriots show interest in A.J. Brown but find the Eagles' trade demands too high.
The Eagles would face $44 million in dead money if they trade Brown before June 1, reducing to $16 million after.
Coach Mike Vrabel hints at potential roster moves, possibly keeping Stefon Diggs while trading for Brown.

title: Bye-bye transponders: E-ZPass switching to stickers
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Massachusetts is transitioning from E-ZPass transponders to free windshield sticker tags starting Sunday.
The new sticker tags use RFID technology for toll reading and cost 55 cents to produce.
State officials project a yearly saving of $7.4 million from replacing transponders with sticker tags.

title: Woburn man charged with evading $1.2 million in income tax
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Jean Brito of Woburn indicted for allegedly evading over $1.2 million in personal income taxes from 2018 to 2023.
Brito, owner of Boston Quality Cleaning Services, accused of underreporting more than $20 million in business income.
Brito released on conditions; next court date set for March 18 in Middlesex Superior Court.

title: Beware the birds: Bird flu confirmed in Boston
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Bird flu confirmed in Boston's Emerald Necklace park system, prompting a public health advisory.
The risk of human infection is currently low, but officials urge avoiding contact with park wildlife.
CDC reports 71 human cases of bird flu since 2024, with symptoms mimicking the seasonal flu.

title: Top NFL Draft prospect Fernando Mendoza enthralled by possibility of Tom Brady mentorship: ‘It would mean so much’
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Fernando Mendoza, top 2026 NFL Draft prospect, is excited about potential mentorship from Tom Brady at the Raiders.
Mendoza, a Heisman winner with Indiana, is expected to be the first overall pick and spoke with Brady by phone.
The standout college QB threw 41 touchdowns and had an NCAA-best passer rating, leading Indiana to a national title.

title: 5 must-watch movies & TV shows streaming right now
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: 'Kiss of the Spider Woman' starring Jennifer Lopez is now streaming on Hulu.
'Paul McCartney: Man on the Run' documentary directed by Morgan Neville available on Prime Video.
'Bridgerton' Season 4 Part 2, focused on Benedict Bridgerton, is streaming on Netflix.

title: Red Sox’ Roman Anthony and Ceddanne Rafaela say they’re fine after outfield collision
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Roman Anthony and Ceddanne Rafaela collided in the outfield during a spring training game against the Braves.
Both players stayed in the game after the collision, each recording a hit in subsequent innings.
Manager Alex Cora attributed the collision to a miscommunication between Anthony and Rafaela.

title: Alex Cora to donate $20K to Jimmy Fund when 2026 Red Sox hit this milestone
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Alex Cora pledges $20,000 to the Jimmy Fund when a Red Sox player hits 20 home runs in 2026.
Cora's donation would be his largest public contribution to the Jimmy Fund, supporting cancer care and research.
In 2025, Trevor Story and Wilyer Abreu were the only Red Sox players to exceed 20 home runs.

title: N.H. House advances bill targeting ‘indoctrination’ in public schools
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: The New Hampshire House advanced the CHARLIE Act to regulate teachings on race, American history, and LGBTQ+ issues.
The bill prohibits instruction promoting division or anti-constitutional messages, requiring a neutral or patriotic educational stance.
Teachers could face disciplinary actions for violations, and individuals may sue schools for up to $10,000 per infraction.
